title: The King's Demons
dialogue_triumphs: Tegan: 'Look at the size of that bed.' Doctor: 'Another way of keeping warm.'
goofs: The Master's iron maiden TARDIS has an anachronistic Elizabethan ruff.
The history is inaccurate, as the Magna Carta's importance was fabricated in the 17th century: it achieved very little in the 13th century.
French was still the language of the court in the early 13th century, so why does only Sir Gilles speak it?

continuity_notes.name: The Master
continuity_notes.description: Time Lord renegade and the Doctor's arch-nemesis
continuity_notes.current_status: Attempting to impersonate King John and wreck the Magna Carta

continuity_notes.name: Kamelion
continuity_notes.description: Shape-shifting android with its own mind, controlled psychokinetically
continuity_notes.current_status: Being used by the Master to impersonate King John

continuity_notes.name: Tissue Compression Eliminator
continuity_notes.description: The Master's weapon, capable of shrinking victims
continuity_notes.current_status: Referred to as a 'compressor', left switched on by the Doctor

continuity_notes.name: Tegan
continuity_notes.current_status: Able to operate the TARDIS on her own

continuity_notes.name: Turlough
continuity_notes.current_status: Mentions plans to visit his home planet

continuity_notes.name: Eye of Orion
continuity_notes.description: A peaceful location previously visited by Turlough

roots: The King refers to various demonic entities ('Can this be Lilith?').

locations.name: England
locations.current_status: 4 March 1215, during the reign of King John

untold_adventures: Turlough's previous visit to the Eye of Orion
additional_notes: The episode is a twentieth-anniversary special, 90 minutes long and in color.
bottom_line: Some nice medieval dialogue, and the budget is just big enough to make the thing look convincing, but it's all very inconsequential, the Doctor admitting that the Master's plan to wreck the Magna Carta is 'small-time villainy by his standards'.
